awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Direct, Nozzle-Free Printing of Functional Nanomaterials Using Ultrasound Bubble Cavitation
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to provide a robust understanding of the fundamental science behind the working mechanism of a nozzle-free liquid-jetting system. Widely employed state-of-the-art printing techniques rely primarily on the use of nozzles to deposit materials. Nozzles can get clogged, which adversely affects printing reliability and reproducibility. This problem becomes more significant when the nozzle diameter is reduced for high-resolution printing, which is in increasing demand. Additionally, it is difficult to print inks or pastes that contain particles, flakes, and high-aspect ratio nanomaterials. This award supports research to provide knowledge for the development of a nozzle-free additive manufacturing process, which can eliminate clogs and enable narrower jet streams required for high resolution printing. The ultrasound bubble cavitation process enables deposition of different types, shapes, and sizes of nanomaterials on rigid and flexible substrates. The absence of nozzles eliminates clogging problems. Nanomaterial-based additively manufactured devices find a wide range of applications, from electronics to biomaterials to sensors. Therefore, the results from this study benefits the printing industry and the national economy. This project involves several disciplines including applied physics, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, bioengineering, and materials science. The multi-disciplinary research creates a unique environment, which helps broaden participation of women and underrepresented groups in research and positively impacts engineering education. The project uses YouTube and other social media platforms to disseminate knowledge to a wider community.

The project studies a liquid jetting system enabled by a single cavitation bubble created by laser-generated focused ultrasound to print various nanostructures.  The ultrasound bubble cavitation printing process is nozzle-less, thus avoiding the clogging problems in existing nozzle-based additive manufacturing techniques. However, a robust understanding of the fundamental mechanism behind the liquid jetting and energy conversion processes involved is needed to realize the full application potential of using this technique for additive manufacturing. To understand the ultrasonic liquid jetting mechanism, the research team develops models of acoustic interference at the air-liquid interface and cavitation zone, laser-flash shadowgraphy to capture the hydrodynamics of bubble formation and jetting, and bubble formation dynamics as a function of varying physical parameters. To design efficient an optoacoustic transducer, the team studies the effect of laser parameters on thermal transport properties in light-absorbing nanocomposite materials leading to high pressure amplitudes, investigates design aspects of photoacoustic lens leading to high focal gain, and fabricates composite lenses and determines the geometric gain, peak pressure amplitude, and lens breakdown factors. Finally, the team prints nanomaterial films, and compares the quality and characteristics of printed films against those obtained with traditional printing systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on developing a new type of additive manufacturing process, namely a nozzle-free printing of functional materials enabled by photoacoustic actuation, which eliminates the nozzle-clogging issue that challenges traditional ink-jet printing process, especially for ink formulation with high viscosity or materials with high aspect ratios, such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs).

The printing results have been compared with those obtained by ink-jet printing and aerosol printing; printed CNT thin film transistors were demonstrated and the advantages of the new printing process is shown by experiment, especially the fast-printing capability, e.g. single pass able to deposit more materials than multiple-passes by inkjet printing method.

We have investigated in-depth the printing mechanisms, especially the dynamics of the jetting process and how to control the direction of the main jet and suppress the satellite jets that can cause the randomness of the printed inks at the edges, causing edge roughness.

We have proved experimentally that the photoacoustic printing can indeed handle very viscous ink materials and those that can easily clog the traditional inkjet printing head. In the last phase program where both university teams are producing CNT based printed thin film transistors, we learnt from our Boise State Univ. collaborator that they need to clean the print-head often in order to carry out successful printing of an array of CNT transistor channels.

We have been improving our hardware capability, especially for printing transistor channels on pre-patterned substrate to enable registration and coarse alignment.

Through a Data Science supplement award, we aim to discover the correlation between printer parameters and print quality, then using this knowledge to improve print results overall. Three separate types of printers are being used: inkjet, aerosol jet, and plasma jet. Each one of these printers varies greatly from each other and has different parameters that can be adjusted. Data collection is done by collaborators at Boise State University. PhD and undergraduate students at UMich performed image analysis and developed machine learning algorithms.

We have successfully obtained working CNT thin film transistors. Interestingly, multiple-pass printing by photoacoustic method, followed by water cleaning to remove residuals showed very high percentage working devices, while those done by inkjet hardly have any CNTs left in the channel. The exact reason is still under investigation, but could be attributed to the large momentum transferred to the deposited material making the CNTs better connected and not removable by water rinse. 

We have successfully extended the photoacoustic method from printing semiconductor ink materials to directly printing organic semiconductor material in the solid form. The motivation is that in almost all semiconductor devices material exists in solid form, but in order to suit the fabrication process, e.g. inkjet printing, they have to be dissolved in organic solvent, and during and after printing the solvents need to be driven out to build working devices. Therefore the ability to directly print/deposit material in solid state will be highly desirable, not only to preserve the material property but also simplify the fabrication and reduce the processing steps.

Last but not the least, the project provided excellent opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students from different technical backgrounds at two schools to interact and collaborate closely to accomplish the common goal.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2022
Modified by: L. Jay Guo
